Campaign promise: The expert's verdict highlights that Scott Walker made a campaign promise in 2002 to cut the Milwaukee County executive's salary by $60,000 per year. This promise was made in response to a scandal over lavish county pensions.
Reduction in giveback: The expert's verdict mentions that Scott Walker reduced his annual giveback from $60,000 to $10,000. This reduction in giveback was pointed out by his Democratic opponent, Milwaukee Mayor Tom Barrett, who referred to a 2002 Walker flier that included the promise to reduce the county exec salary by $60,000 per year.
Verification from official sources: The expert's verdict states that the figures regarding Scott Walker's salary giveback were obtained from the Walker gubernatorial campaign and the Milwaukee County Department of Administrative Services. Both offices agreed on the figures, providing official verification of the claim.
Calculation of returned amounts: The expert's verdict explains how the returned amounts were calculated. It mentions that taking into account the partial year Walker served after being elected in 2002, and an odd number of pay periods in 2003 through 2005, Walker returned the equivalent of $60,000 per year from 2002 through 2007. In 2008, he returned $18,846, and in 2009 and 2010, he returned the equivalent of $10,000 per year, along with additional checks to the county.
